sen.j: 小笠原流（おがさわらりゅう）は、武家故実の流派、それに含まれる騎射の流派から始まる諸芸の流派である。
sen.e: The Ogasawara school provides various arts originated in the school of Kisha (to shoot an arrow on horseback) which is included in ancient practices of customs of samurai family.
The Ogasawara-ryu is a school of traditional samurai arts, that was originally founded to teach equestrian archery (kisha).
sen.cmt: As the translator said, the original isn't easy to understand but I think this gets the point across
sen.e: The Ogasawara-ryu is a school of traditional samurai arts, that was originally founded to teach equestrian archery (kisha).

sen.j: 弓馬術礼法小笠原流や小笠原流煎茶道などがある。
sen.e: There are Ogasawara school of archery, horsemanship and manners and sencha tea service of Ogasawara school, etc.
The school teaches the Ogasawara style of archery, horsemanship and etiquette, and the Ogasawara Tea Ceremony.
The school teaches the Ogasawara style of archery, horsemanship and etiquette, and the Ogasawara Tea Ceremony.

sen.j: なお、守護大名としての特定の小笠原氏に関しては、別項目を参照の事。
sen.e: Regarding a particular Ogasawara clan who was serving as Shugo Guardian Feudal Lord, see the related section.
For information on the Ogasawara Clan of daimyo, see the relevant section.
For information on the Ogasawara Clan of daimyo, see the relevant section.

sen.j: 「礼儀作法といえば小笠原」といわれるほどのマナー作法における正統流派だが、その歴史は鎌倉時代にまでさかのぼる武家作法の高家。
sen.e: Given the statement that 'etiquette and the Ogasawara name are almost synonyms', the Ogasawara school is an orthodox school of teaching manners and etiquette, and their history background was they were from a Koke family (a honorable family) in the Kamakura period which was involved in the education of samurai manner.
sen.cmt: ここでの高家は、名門、名家を指すと思われ、必ずしも江戸時代に特定されたものでないようです。
sen.e: The school is so well-known as a school of traditional etiquette that it is said that 'etiquette is Ogasawara' and its history can be traced back to the Kamakura-era high-ranking family involved in teaching samurai etiquette.

The school is so well-known as a school of traditional etiquette that it is said that 'etiquette is Ogasawara' and its history can be traced back to the Kamakura-period high-ranking family involved in teaching samurai etiquette.

sen.j: 高倉天皇にその名を頂いたとされる初代の小笠原長清が源頼朝に糾法（きゅうほう）指南役に命じられたことに端を発する。
sen.e: The Ogasawara school is believed to have started with the circumstances that the 1st generation of the family Nagakiyo OGASAWARA whose name had been given by the Emperor Takakura was appointed by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo as grand master of Kyuho (manners in times of peace and campaign strategy in times of war.)
The school originated when the founder of the Ogasawara Clan, Nagakiyo OGASAWARA, who is said to have received the name from Emperor Takakura, was appointed by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo to teach "kyuho".
sen.cmt: Revised for clarity - since "糾法" is explained in the following sentence, I left it as is here.
sen.e: The school originated when the founder of the Ogasawara Clan, Nagakiyo OGASAWARA, who is said to have received the name from Emperor Takakura, was appointed by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo to teach "kyuho".

sen.j: 糾法とは弓と馬を意味し、七代目の小笠原貞宗は南北朝時代 (日本)に後醍醐天皇に仕え「弓馬の妙蘊に達し、かつ礼法を新定して、武家の定式とするなり」という御手判を賜り、このとき「弓・馬・礼」の三法をもって小笠原流とする武家作法としてのその位置づけが確立。
sen.e: The Kyuho is related to an archery and horsemanship related manner, and while the 7th generation of the family Sadamune OGASAWARA was serving the Emperor Godaigo during the Nanbokucho era (Japan), he was given an otehan (statement written by the Emperor himself) that 'he has to make archery and horsemanship excellent and establish manner and courtesy related rules which samurai families should follow as determined styles for samurai families', and at the same time, it was decided that three categories/manners including 'archery, horsemanship and courtesy' would be defined as samurai manner in the Ogasawara school.
sen.cmt: 最後の方の日本語が分かりにくいです。
sen.e: "Kyuho" was defined as archery and horsemanship, and the 7th head of the clan, Sadamune OGASAWARA, who served Emperor Godaigo during the Nanbokucho era, was asked by the Emperor 'to improve archery and horsemanship skills and to set new standards for manners, which samurai families should follow'; it was at this time that the Ogasawara school's three arts of 'archery, horsemanship and courtesy' were established as samurai manners.

"Kyuho" was defined as archery and horsemanship, and the 7th head of the clan, Sadamune OGASAWARA, who served Emperor Godaigo during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts, was asked by the Emperor 'to improve archery and horsemanship skills and to set new standards for manners, which samurai families should follow'; it was at this time that the Ogasawara school's three arts of 'archery, horsemanship and courtesy' were established as samurai manners.

sen.j: 礼法だけが独立したように取り扱われることがあるが、その歴史的背景から、弓と馬と礼の三つが揃ってはじめて小笠原流とするのが適切である。
sen.e: It sometimes happens that only the school of etiquette is separately and independently focused on in the Ogasawara school, but according to its historical background, it is appropriate to consider that the Ogasawara school is made complete with all three categories/manners including archery, horsemanship and courtesy.

Occasionally, only manners are taught but, taking into account the historical background, the Ogasawara-ryu can only be considered complete with the three arts of 'archery, horsemanship and courtesy'.

Occasionally, only manners are taught but, taking into account the historical background, the Ogasawara-ryu can only be considered complete with the three arts of 'archery, horsemanship and courtesy'.

sen.j: 小笠原家は代々、総領家（本家）が糾法および小笠原流礼法全般をとりしきり「宗家」となっていたが、惣領家十七代の小笠原長時とその子小笠原貞慶は、戦国大名として武田信玄らと壮絶な戦を繰り広げる中、弓馬礼法の伝統を絶やさないため、永禄5年（1562年）、従兄弟筋にあたる小笠原経長に糾法的伝と系図、記録を携え、弓馬術礼法の道統を託した。
sen.e: In the Ogasawara family, Soryo (a child of Gokenin or Hatamoto family succeeding the family) -ke family (総領家, head family) had played a role of Soke (grand master) by overall managing the Kyuho and the Ogasawara school of etiquette over generations, but when the 17th generation of Soryo (a person succeeding a head family)-ke family (惣領家) Nagatoki OGASAWARA and his son Sadayoshi OGASAWARA as Sengoku daimyo (territorial lord) were in fierce battles against Shingen TAKEDA, in 1562 they met Tsunenaga OGASAWARA (小笠原経長) who was from their cousin family line handed over Kyuho-tekiden (meaning "to be directly succeeded from the master"), a family record and records to him to prevent the horseback archery technique from dying and asked him to ensure doto (formal succession of teaching) regarding the school of archery, horsemanship and courtesy.

The position of "Soke", or Grand Master, who was in charge of "Kyuho" and the Ogasawara style of etiquette, was passed down in the main branch of the family for generations, but in 1562, to prevent the horseback archery technique from dying out, the 17th head of the family, Nagatoki OGASAWARA, and his son Sadayoshi OGASAWARA, who as Sengoku daimyo were involved in fierce battles against Shingen TAKEDA, handed the art of "kyuho", the family geneology and records to their cousin, Tsunenaga OGASAWARA, entrusting him with passing on the arts of archery, horsemanship and courtesy.
sen.cmt: Revised for clarity - I think "惣領家" is probably a typo for "総領家" Punctuation
sen.e: The position of 'Soke', or Grand Master, who was in charge of "Kyuho" and the Ogasawara style of etiquette, was passed down in Soryo-ke (the main branch of the family) for generations, but in 1562, to prevent the horseback archery technique from dying out, the 17th head of the family, Nagatoki OGASAWARA, and his son Sadayoshi OGASAWARA, who as daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) in the Sengoku period were involved in fierce battles against Shingen TAKEDA, handed the art of "kyuho", the family geneology and records to their cousin, Tsunenaga OGASAWARA, entrusting him with passing on the arts of archery, horsemanship and courtesy.
sen.cmt: 戦国大名の定訳"Soke"→'Soke'「惣領家」を Soryo-ke として、後にも何度か出てくるため追記しました。

sen.j: 道統とは小笠原の弓・馬・礼の三法の総取り仕切り役の正統継承を意味し、「宗家」にあたる。
sen.e: Doto means a formal succession of sotorishikiri-yaku person (head of the persons who are in charge of something) and the sotorishikiri-yaku person manages the three categories of archery, horsemanship and courtesy of Ogasawara, and is applicable for 'soke.'
This formal handing down of the position of the person in charge of the three arts of archery, horsemanship and courtesy is known as "doto".
sen.cmt: Revised to make more relevant to non-Japanese speakers
sen.e: This formal handing down of the position of the person in charge of the three arts of archery, horsemanship and courtesy of Ogasawara-ryu school is known as Doto, equivalent to 'Soke'
sen.cmt: 「小笠原流の」と、「宗家にあたる」を追記しました。("doto"をDotoとしました。）

sen.j: つまりこのとき、本家としての総領家と、弓馬礼法の宗家との家がはじめて歴史的に分離したことになる。
sen.e: Upon the delivery of the Kyuho-tekiden, etc. described above, the separation of Soryo-ke family (総領家) as head family and Soke for the school of archery, horsemanship and courtesy was for the first time realized in the history.
This was the first time that the position of "Soke" had been separated from the main family.
This was the first time that the position of 'Soke' had been separated from the main family.
sen.cmt: " " →' 'ＮＣによりかなり簡略な文となっていますが、ＯＫだと思います。

sen.j: 両家の家紋も異なり、総領家筋は三階菱。
sen.e: The both families' crests differed, and a crest for the Soryo-ke family (総領家) line was Sangaibishi (three rhombus.)
The crests for each family were different, with that of the main family comprising of three diamonds (Sangaibishi).
The crests for each family were different, with that of the main family comprising of three diamonds (Sangaibishi).

sen.j: 宗家筋は三階菱に十文字をいれたものとなっている。
sen.e: A crest for the Soke family line is Sangaibishi with the shape of a cross in it.
The crest for the Soke family line has a cross superimposed on the Sangaibishi.
The crest for the Soke family line has a cross superimposed on the Sangaibishi.

sen.j: 総領家筋はその後、小倉藩に入り歴代当主が藩主となっている。
sen.e: The Soryo-ke family (総領家) line joined the domain of Kokura and their family heads served the lord of domain.
The main branch of the family moved to Kokura Domain, becoming Lords of the domain.
The main branch of the family moved to Kokura Domain, becoming Lords of the domain.

sen.j: 明治に入ってからは伯爵となり、東京新宿に残されている有名な「小笠原伯爵邸」は、総領家第三十代の小笠原長幹が建立したものである。
sen.e: In the Meiji period, they were granted a rank of earl, and a famous building called 'Lord Ogasawara residence', which has been restored in Shinjuku Tokyo, was built at the request of the 30th generation of the family Nagayoshi OGASAWARA.
In the Meiji period, they were granted the rank of earl, and the famous 'Lord Ogasawara's residence', built in Shinjuku, Tokyo by the 30th head of the family, Nagayoshi OGASAWARA, is still standing.

In the Meiji period, they were granted the rank of earl, and the famous 'Lord Ogasawara's residence', built in Shinjuku, Tokyo by the 30th head of the Soryo-ke family, Nagayoshi OGASAWARA, is still standing.

sen.j: 平成二十年現在、総領家の当主は第三十三代小笠原長雅。
sen.e: As of 2008, the family head of the Soryo-ke family is the 33rd generation Nagamasa OGASAWARA.
As of 2008, the head of the Soryo-ke family is the 33rd generation Nagamasa OGASAWARA.
As of 2008, the head of the Soryo-ke family is the 33rd generation Nagamasa OGASAWARA.

sen.j: また、道統を継いだ小笠原経長は徳川家康と拝謁し、その子孫は歴代徳川将軍に仕え、宗家を継承。
sen.e: Tsunenaga OGASAWARA who accepted Doto (the formal succession of teaching) had a chance to meet Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, and his offspring used to serve Shogun Tokunaga and succeeded the Soke family.
Tsunenaga OGASAWARA, who had inherited the "doto", met Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, and his descendants served the Tokugawa Shogunate, passing down the position of Soke.
Tsunenaga OGASAWARA, who had inherited the Doto, met Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, and his descendants served the Tokugawa Shogunate, passing down the position of Soke.

sen.j: 八代将軍徳川吉宗の命により新儀式としての流鏑馬を制定し、高田馬場で度々行ったりもしている。
sen.e: He established Yabusame horseback archery as a new ritual ceremony at the direction of the 8th Shogun Yoshimune TOKUGAWA, and the Yabusame seemed to be performed several times in Takada no Baba (riding course.)
At the direction of the 8th Shogun, Yoshimune TOKUGAWA, a new ritual known as yabusame horseback archery was established and performed several times at Takada no Baba riding ground.
At the direction of the 8th Shogun, Yoshimune TOKUGAWA, a new ritual known as yabusame horseback archery was established and performed several times at Takada no Baba riding ground.

sen.j: 明治に入ってからは東京神田に弓馬術礼法小笠原教場を開設。
sen.e: In the Meiji period, Kyubajyutsu Reihou Ogasawara Kyohjyo Ogasawara Kyojo (school of Japanese archery, horsemanship and courtesy) was opened in Kanda, Tokyo.
In the Meiji period, Kyubajyutsu Reihou Ogasawara Kyohjyo Ogasawara Kyojo (school of Japanese archery, horsemanship and courtesy) was opened in Kanda, Tokyo.
In the Meiji period, Kyubajyutsu Reihou Ogasawara Kyohjyo Ogasawara Kyojo (school of Japanese archery, horsemanship and courtesy) was opened in Kanda, Tokyo.
sen.cmt: Kyubajyutsu Reihou→ローマ字表記が用語集と違いますが、ホームページのものなのでそのままです。

sen.j: 現在、小笠原清忠が第三十一代宗家。
sen.e: Currently, Kiyotada OGASAWARA is the 31st patriarch.
Currently, the 31st partriarch is Kiyotada OGASAWARA.
Currently, the 31st patriarch is Kiyotada OGASAWARA.

sen.j: 正統な弓馬礼法の継承者として、明治神宮や熱田神宮、伊勢神宮、靖国神社、鶴岡八幡宮などで、年間四十回以上の公的な神事を執り行っている。
sen.e: He is an formal successor of the kyubarei-ho (school of archery, horsemanship and courtesy) and has managed public shinji festivals over forty times a year at Meiji Jingu Shrine, Atsuta Jingu Shrine, Ise Jingu Shrine, Yasukun-jinja Shrine and Tsuruoka Hachimangu Shrine.

He is the official successor of the arts of archery, horsemanship and courtesy and holds over forty public rituals a year at shrines including Meiji-jingu Shrine, Atsuta-jingu Shrine, Ise-jingu Shrine, Yasukuni-jinja Shrine and Tsuruoka Hachimangu Shrine.

He is the official successor of the arts of archery, horsemanship and courtesy and holds over 40 public rituals a year at shrines including Meiji-jingu Shrine, Atsuta-jingu Shrine, Ise-jingu Shrine, Yasukuni-jinja Shrine and Tsurugaoka Hachimangu Shrine.

sen.j: なお嫡男は小笠原清基。
sen.e: The heir is Kiyomoto OGASAWARA.
The heir is Kiyomoto OGASAWARA.
The heir is Kiyomoto OGASAWARA.

sen.j: 現在、特定非営利活動法人 小笠原流・小笠原教場の理事長。
sen.e: He is a director of Ogasawara School Ogasawara Kyohjyo as a specified nonprofit corporation.
He is the director of the Ogasawara-ryu Ogasawara Kyohjyo nonprofit corporation.
He is the director of the Ogasawara-ryu Ogasawara Kyohjyo nonprofit corporation.

sen.j: 小笠原流礼法は登録商標（商標登録番号 第3076080号）となっていて小笠原教場以外が、「小笠原流礼法」の名称を使用して教えることは禁じられている。
sen.e: Ogasawara School Reihou is a registered trademark (Registration Number of Trademark 3076080), and the use of the naming 'Ogasawara Ryu Reihou' for teaching purposes is prohibited.
Ogasawara-ryu Reihou is a registered trademark (Registration Number 3076080), and the use of the 'Ogasawara-ryu Reihou' name by other institutions is prohibited.
Ogasawara-ryu Reihou is a registered trademark (Registration Number 3076080), and the use of the 'Ogasawara-ryu Reihou' name by other institutions is prohibited.

sen.j: 小笠原流は「弓・馬・礼」の三法をもって小笠原流とするが、その正統な継承権を有する家元のこと。
sen.e: Ogasawara school consists of three manners/categories including 'archery, horsemanship and courtesy', and represents Iemoto (a head of a school) who is entitled to officially succeeding the Ogasawara school.
The Ogasawara-ryu consists of the three arts of 'archery, horsemanship and courtesy', which are officially handed down by the Iemoto (head of the school).
The Ogasawara-ryu consists of the three arts of 'archery, horsemanship and courtesy', which are officially handed down by the Iemoto (head of the school).

sen.j: 道統（どうとう）とも言い、現在の正式な宗家は平成6年（1994年）に31世を継承した小笠原清忠である。
sen.e: It also means Doto (formal succession of teaching), and the current official Soke is Kiyotada OGASAWARA who succeeded the 31st Soke in 1994.
This is also known as "doto", and the current official Soke is Kiyotada OGASAWARA, who became the 31st Soke in 1994.
This is also known as Doto, and the current official Soke is Kiyotada OGASAWARA, who became the 31st Soke in 1994.

sen.j: その儀式は神奈川県の鎌倉・鶴岡八幡宮で執り行われた。
sen.e: It was performed at Kamakura Tsuruoka Hachimangu Shrine in Kanagawa Prefecture.
The ceremony was performed at Kamakura Tsuruoka Hachimangu Shrine in Kanagawa Prefecture.
The ceremony was performed at Kamakura Tsurugaoka Hachimangu Shrine in Kanagawa Prefecture.

tit.e: Sencha tea service of Ogasawara school

sen.j: 小笠原流煎茶道（おがさわらりゅうせんちゃどう）は小笠原長清の父、加賀美遠光以来の作法とされる。
sen.e: Sencha tea service of Ogasawara school is a manner which is believed to have been started by Tomitsu KAGAMI, father of Nagakiyo OGASAWARA.
The Ogasawara-ryu sencha tea ceremony is believed to have been started by Nagakiyo OGASAWARA's father, Tomitsu KAGAMI.
The Ogasawara-ryu sencha tea ceremony is believed to have been started by Nagakiyo OGASAWARA's father, Tomitsu KAGAMI.

sen.j: 小笠原流作法を基礎とした煎茶道の流派である。
sen.e: It is a school of Sencha tea Service which is based on the manner of Ogasawara school.
The ceremony uses unground sencha tea, as oppoosed to powdered matcha, and is based on Ogasawara-ryu manners.
sen.cmt: Revised to make clearer for non-Japanese
sen.e: The ceremony uses unground sencha tea, as oppoosed to powdered matcha, and is based on Ogasawara-ryu manners.

sen.j: 平成3年（1991年）財団法人小笠原流煎茶道が設立された。
sen.e: In 1991, Ogasawara Sencha Service School was established.
In 1991, the Ogasawara Sencha Service School was established.
sen.cmt: OK- the name sounds a bit strange in English, but it's what they have on their webpage
sen.e: In 1991, the Ogasawara Sencha Service School was established.

sen.j: 現在の家元は小笠原秀道（しゅうどう）。
sen.e: The current school head is Shudo OGASAWARA.
The current school head is Shudo OGASAWARA.
The current school head is Shudo OGASAWARA.

sen.j: 小笠原古流、小笠原家茶道古流などと呼ばれる。
sen.e: It is called Old Ogasawara School or Old Ogasawara Tea Service School.
It is known as the Old Ogasawara School or Old Ogasawara Tea Ceremony School.
It is known as the Old Ogasawara School or Old Ogasawara Tea Ceremony School.

sen.j: 室町時代の茶人村田珠光の弟子古市澄胤の4代後の古市了和が九州豊前国小倉藩（福岡県北九州市）主小笠原忠真に仕えて始まった。
sen.e: The 4th head tea master Yoshikazu FURUICHI (古市了和), started serving Tadazane OGASAWARA, the lord of the Kokura domain, Buzen Province, Kyushu (Kitakyushu City, Fukuoka Prefecture) and in a later year the art of Macha tea service called Old Ogasawara School was commenced. Yoshikazu FURUICHI succeeded Choin FURUICHI to become the 4th head tea master, who was an apprentice of Juko MURATA as a master of ceremonial tea in the Muromachi period.

The ceremony began with the tea master, Yoshikazu FURUICHI, who served Tadazane OGASAWARA, the Lord of Kokura Domain, Buzen Province, Kyushu (present-day Kitakyushu City, Fukuoka Prefecture), and who was the 4th head following Choin FURUICHI, who had been an apprentice of the Muromachi-era tea master, Juko MURATA.

The ceremony began with the tea master, Yoshikazu FURUICHI, who served Tadazane OGASAWARA, the Lord of Kokura Domain, Buzen Province, Kyushu (present-day Kitakyushu City, Fukuoka Prefecture), and who was the 4th head following Choin FURUICHI, who had been an apprentice of the Muromachi-period tea master, Juko MURATA.

sen.j: 千利休や千宗旦らを祖としていない茶道である。
sen.e: This art of Matcha tea ceremony is not related to the tea ceremonies which were developed by SEN no Rikyu and SEN no Sotan as a patriarch.
This Matcha tea ceremony is not related to the tea ceremonies developed by SEN no Rikyu and SEN no Sotan.
sen.cmt: Deleted "art of", "which were", " as a patriarch"
sen.e: This Matcha tea ceremony is not related to the tea ceremonies developed by SEN no Rikyu and SEN no Sotan.

sen.j: 小笠原流を名乗っていないが、上記忠真の弟で三河吉田藩（愛知県豊橋市）主小笠原忠知（その子孫は明治維新時は肥前国唐津藩主、現在の佐賀県唐津市）が、三千家の祖の父の千宗旦の宗旦四天王の山田宗偏を迎えて興された流派がある。
sen.e: Tadatomo OGASAWARA (his offspring used to serve the lord of the Karatsu domain, Hizen Province during the Meiji Restoration - currently, Karatsu City, Saga Prefecture) whose elder brother was Tadazane OGASAWARA and the lord of the Mikawa-Yoshida domain (Toyohashi City, Aichi Prefecture) invited Sohen YAMADA, one of the big four of Sotan who were particularly working hard for SEN no Sotan, and in a later year, a new school was developed under the name different from the Ogasawara school. SEN no Sotan was the patriarch of Sansenke (three schools of tea ceremony: Omotesenke, Urasenke and Mushakojisenke) and a father of the big four of Sotan.

Tadazane's younger brother, the Lord of the Mikawa-Yoshida Domain (present-day Toyohashi City, Aichi Prefecture), Tadatomo OGASAWARA (whose descendants were lords of Karatsu Domain, Hizen Province - present-day Karatsu City, Saga Prefecture - during the Meiji Restoration) invited
sen.cmt: Revised to rejoin to cell F55
sen.e: Tadazane's younger brother, the Lord of the Mikawa-Yoshida Domain (present-day Toyohashi City, Aichi Prefecture), and Tadatomo OGASAWARA (whose descendants were lords of Karatsu Domain, Hizen Province [present-day Karatsu City, Saga Prefecture] at the time of the Meiji Restoration) invited Sohen YAMADA, one of the 'Four Heavenly Kings' (as the closest followers of the founder of the Sansenke tea ceremony, SEN no Sotan, were known), to revive the matcha ceremony, though separately from the Ogasawara-ryu.
sen.cmt: 一文に訳し直しました。

sen.j: これが宗偏流茶道である。
sen.e: This was Sohen school of tea ceremony.
This was Sohen school of tea ceremony.
This is Sohen school of tea ceremony.

sen.j: 但し、これは千家の流派であるため、小笠原流とは呼ばない。
sen.e: It is Senke school, so not called Ogasawara school.
It is Senke school, so not called Ogasawara school.
It is Senke school, so not called Ogasawara school.

sen.j: 小笠原流は、源頼朝の臣である小笠原長清を祖とする武家故実の流派である。
sen.e: Ogasawara school's patriarch was Nagakiyo OGASAWARA who used to serve Yoritomo MINAMOTO, and the Ogasawara school is aimed to learn ancient practices of customs of samurai family.
The founder of the Ogasawara-ryu was Nagakiyo OGASAWARA, who served Yoritomo MINAMOTO, to teach the ancient practices and customs of samurai family.
The founder of the Ogasawara-ryu was Nagakiyo OGASAWARA, who served Yoritomo MINAMOTO, to teach the ancient practices and customs of samurai family.

sen.j: 小笠原姓は長清が高倉天皇から賜ったとされ、源頼朝をはじめとする武将の糾法（弓馬術礼法）師範を代々つとめていた。
sen.e: The family name Ogasawara is believed to have been given by Emperor Takakura, and used to act as Kyuho master for Yoritomo MINAMOTO and other warlords over generations.

The family name Ogasawara is believed to have been given by Emperor Takakura, and starting with Yoritomo MINAMOTO, the clan served for generations as instructors of martial arts and etiquette to military commanders.
The family name Ogasawara is believed to have been given by Emperor Takakura, and starting with Yoritomo MINAMOTO, the clan served for generations as instructors of Kyuho to military commanders.

sen.j: その後後醍醐天皇の時代には七代小笠原貞宗（礼法家）と小笠原常興（弓馬術礼法家）、が『修身論』と『体用論』をまとめ、今の小笠原流の基礎を築いている。
sen.e: During the rule of Emperor Godaigo, 7th generation Sadamune OGASAWARA (a family as a master of manners) and Tsuneoki (常興) OGASAWARA (individual with Japanese horseback archery technique) authored "Shushinron (moral training theory)" and "Taiyoron (theory about how to deal with our bodies)", respectively, that was likely to help the basis of Ogasawara school to be constructed.

During the rule of Emperor Godaigo, the 7th generation Sadamune OGASAWARA (from the school of manners) and Tsuneoki (常興) OGASAWARA (from the school of horseback archery) authored "Shushinron (moral training theory)" and "Taiyoron (theory about how to deal with our bodies)", respectively, laying the foundations for theh modern Ogasawara-ryu.

During the rule of Emperor Godaigo, the 7th generation Sadamune OGASAWARA (from the school of manners) and Tsuneoki (常興) OGASAWARA (from the school of horseback archery) authored "Shushinron (moral training theory)" and "Taiyoron (theory about how to deal with our bodies)", respectively, laying the foundations for the modern Ogasawara-ryu.

sen.j: 「小笠原は日本武士の定式たるべし」と後醍醐天皇より「王」の字の紋を与えられる。
sen.e: Emperor Godaigo stated that 'Ogasawara has to be a determined manner or role model for Japanese samurai' and gave a crest representing a letter '王 (king.)'
Emperor Godaigo stated that 'Ogasawara should be the standard for Japanese samurai' and awarded a crest representing the character for king
Emperor Godaigo stated that 'Ogasawara should be the standard for Japanese samurai' and awarded a crest representing the character for king.

sen.j: これが現在にも伝わる三階菱の家紋である。
sen.e: This is a family crest "Sangaibishi" which has been handed down until today.
This is the "Sangaibishi" family crest, which has been handed down until today.
This is the "Sangaibishi" family crest, which has been handed down until today.

sen.j: 室町時代には、足利尊氏の命により、十代・小笠原長秀が伊勢氏、今川氏と共に「三議一統」を編纂。
sen.e: In the Muromachi period, the 10th generation of the family Nagahide OGASAWARA co-authored 'Sangiitto (a book about general knowledge for samurai)' together with the Ise clan and Imagawa clan at the direction of Takauji ASHIKAGA.

In the Muromachi period, at the direction of Takauji ASHIKAGA, the 10th generation of the family, Nagahide OGASAWARA, co-authored 'Sangiitto (a book about general knowledge for samurai)' together with the Ise clan and the Imagawa clan.

In the Muromachi period, at the direction of Takauji ASHIKAGA, the 10th generation of the family, Nagahide OGASAWARA, compiled 'Sangiitto (a book about general knowledge for samurai)' together with the Ise clan and the Imagawa clan.

sen.j: 武士の一般常識をまとめたとされる。
sen.e: The book seemed to cover common sense of samurai warrior.
The book is believed to have covered general samurai wisdom.
The book is believed to have covered general samurai wisdom.

sen.j: 十八代・貞慶は、「三議一統」後に加えられた記述をし、武家礼法を「小笠原礼書七冊」としてまとめる。
sen.e: The 18th generation of the family Sadayoshi wrote up about items which were added after the compilation of 'Sangiitto' to compile 'Ogasawara Manner Book Seven Volumes (小笠原礼書七冊)' of the manners of samurai family.
sen.cmt: "「三議一統」後に加えられた記述をし"の日本文の意味が定かでありません。
sen.e: The 18th generation of the family, Sadayoshi, wrote about changes since the 'Sangiitto', compiling them into the 'Seven Volumes of Ogasawara Etiqutte (小笠原礼書七冊)', which cover samurai etiquette.
The 18th generation of the family, Sadayoshi, wrote about changes since the 'Sangiitto', compiling them into the 'Seven Volumes of Ogasawara Etiqutte', which covered samurai etiquette.
sen.cmt: 漢字不要と考え削除しました。cover→covered

sen.j: 小笠原家は代々、総領家（本家）が糾法および小笠原流礼法全般をとりしきり「宗家」となっていたが、十七代の小笠原長時とその子貞慶は、戦乱の戦国時代に弓馬礼法の伝統を絶やさないため、従兄弟筋にあたる伊豆赤沢の経長に宗家の道統を継承。
sen.e: In the Ogasawara family, Soryo-ke (head family) used to play a role of Soke (grand master) to overall manage the Kyuho and the manners of Ogasawara school over generations, but the 17th generation of the family Nagatoki OGASAWARA and his son Sadayoshi OGASAWARA handed over doto to Tsunenaga (経長) in Izu Akazawa who was from their cousin family line to prevent the horseback archery tradition from dying in the Sengoku period.

The main branch of the Ogasawara family provided the Soke (grand master), in charge of "kyuho" and Ogasawara-ryu manners for generations, but the 17th generation of the family, Nagatoki OGASAWARA and his son Sadayoshi OGASAWARA handed over doto to their cousin, Tsunenaga (経長) from Akazawa, Izu, to prevent the horseback archery tradition from dying out in the turbulent Sengoku period.

The main branch of the Ogasawara family provided the Soke (grand master), in charge of "kyuho" and Ogasawara-ryu manners for generations, but the 17th generation of the family, Nagatoki OGASAWARA and his son Sadayoshi OGASAWARA handed over Doto to their cousin, Tsunenaga from Akazawa, Izu, to prevent the horseback archery tradition from dying out in the turbulent Sengoku period.

sen.j: 道統とは小笠原の弓・馬・礼の三法の総取り仕切り役の正統継承を意味し、一般用語では「宗家」にあたる。
sen.e: The Doto means formal succession from a person who was responsible to manage the three manners of archery, horsemanship and courtesy, and seems equal to 'Soke' in a general term.
Doto means the formal succession of responsibility for the three arts of archery, horsemanship and courtesy, and is equivalent to the more common 'Soke'.
Doto means the formal succession of responsibility for the three arts of archery, horsemanship and courtesy, and is equivalent to the more common 'Soke'.

sen.j: 小笠原流礼法は幕府公式礼法の「お止め流」とされ将軍家にしか指導されず、流儀も次期宗家一人にしかその奥義を伝えられることはなかった。
sen.e: Manners of Ogasawara school were determined to be 'Otome-ryu (school)' of the shogunate's official manners and taught only to the shogun family, so the soke of following generation was only one person who could know the secrets of the school of thoughts or style.
The Ogasawara school of manners was declared 'Otome-ryu' and was only allowed to teach the shogun's family, and the secrets of the style were passed down to one person only.
The Ogasawara school of manners was declared 'Otome-ryu' and was only allowed to teach the shogun's family, and the secrets of the style were passed down to one person only.
sen.cmt: 「次期宗家一人」が「one person only」となっていますが、翻訳者が訳出しているものをdeleteしているので、これで伝わるのだと考えます。

sen.j: 一般武士は将軍家を真似たものと思われる。
sen.e: Ordinary samurai seemed to behave like what the shogun family did.
It is believed that ordinary samurai imitated the shogun family.
It is believed that ordinary samurai imitated the shogun family.

sen.j: 江戸後期や四民平等となった明治には、女学校で礼儀作法が授業に取り入れられるなど、富裕層の町人も作法を学ぶようになるが、小笠原とは関係はない。
sen.e: In the late Edo period and Meiji period in which the whole nation equality was introduced, girls' schools started teaching the class of etiquette and manners and girls from affluent merchants got to learn the manners, that, however, were not related to Ogasawara.

In the late Edo period and Meiji period, which saw the introduction of equality for all people, girls' schools started teaching etiquette classes and affluent merchants were able learn manners, although they were not related to Ogasawara.

In the late Edo period and Meiji period, which saw the introduction of equality for all people, girls' schools started teaching etiquette classes and affluent merchants were able to learn manners, although they were not related to Ogasawara.

sen.j: ただ、「小笠原」というブランドイメージがあるため、中には小笠原を名乗るものもいたという。
sen.e: It seemed that some of groups who were teaching manners were identified as Ogasawara due to the good brand image of 'Ogasawara.'
However, it seems that some of the groups who were teaching manners were using the Ogasawara name due to its prestige.
However, it seems that some of the groups who were teaching manners were using the Ogasawara name due to its prestige.

sen.j: それにより、一般には流派の本質ではない「礼儀作法＝堅苦しい＝小笠原」イメージがついてしまっている。
sen.e: Given the above, generally speaking, apart from the nature of the Ogasawara school, the image of 'courtesy & manners = strict and rigid = Ogasawara' was built.
Due to this, an image of 'courtesy and manners = strict and rigid = Ogasawara' developed, although as a rule this was not what the school advocated.
Due to this, an image of 'courtesy and manners = strict and rigid = Ogasawara' developed, although as a rule this was not what the school advocated.

sen.j: 現在は、全国の神社における年中行事にてその流儀を披露している。
sen.e: Nowadays the Ogasawara school is demonstrated for annual events in shrines and temples all over Japan.
Nowadays, the Ogasawara-ryu is demonstrated at annual events in shrines and temples all over Japan.
Nowadays, the Ogasawara-ryu is demonstrated at annual events in shrines and temples all over Japan.

sen.j: 現在小笠原流宗家は三十一代・小笠原清忠。
sen.e: The current soke of Ogasawara school is the 31st generation of the family Kiyotada OGASAWARA.
The current Soke of the Ogasawara school is the 31st generation of the family, Kiyotada OGASAWARA.
The current Soke of the Ogasawara school is the 31st generation of the family, Kiyotada OGASAWARA.

sen.j: 近年、本家筋の子孫が小笠原流礼法の商標を無断で登録して宗家を称したことにより裁判沙汰になった事実がある。
sen.e: In a recent year, there was an incident that offspring from the head family line illegally registered the trademark of Ogasawara-ryu Reiho and was identified as Soke, resulting in legal proceedings.
Recently, desecendants of the main branch of the family were taken to court for registering Ogasawara-ryu Reiho as a trademark and using the Soke title.
Recently, desecendants of the main branch of the family were taken to court for registering Ogasawara-ryu Reiho as a trademark and using the Soke title.

sen.j: しかしこれについては一般に思われている惣領家と宗家でもめている訳ではない。
sen.e: But, this court case is not the one which has been fought between Soryo-ke family and Soke-family, as generally considered.
However, this was not an argument between the main branch and the Soke, as is generally assumed.
However, this was not an argument between the main branch and the Soke, as is generally assumed.

sen.j: 惣領家当主と宗家筋自体は先代も含めて現在も交流があり、一般に思われているお家騒動や確執といった類のものは両家の間には見られない。
sen.e: The head of Soryo-ke family and Soke still maintain communications with each other as well as past heads, and neither family feuds nor battles do not seem to exist between both families, as generally thought.

The head of the main branch and the Soke still maintain communications with each other, as well as with past heads, and neither family feuds nor battles seem to exist between the families, as is usually believed.

The head of the main branch and the Soke still maintain communications with each other, as well as with past heads, and neither family feuds nor battles seem to exist between the families, as is usually believed.

sen.j: 裁判沙汰はあくまでも、商標の無断登録ならびに「宗家」無断呼称した特定人物との間との問題。
sen.e: These legal proceedings have been taken against a certain person who made an illegal registration of their trademark and illegally designated him/herself as 'Soke.'
These legal proceedings have been taken against a certain person who made an illegal registration of the trademark and illegally designated him/herself as 'Soke.'
These legal proceedings have been taken against a certain person who made an illegal registration of the trademark and illegally designated him/herself as 'Soke.'

sen.j: 現在、総領家三十二世の姪、小笠原敬承斎なる宗家と称する者が小笠原伯爵邸を教場として教授しているが、（1）歴史的に小笠原弓馬術礼法の三法をもって小笠原流とする本流に反すること、（2）全国各地の神社での神事を行っていないこと、（3）弓馬術は武家作法で、歴史的に男系一子相伝、という3点の事実から、敬承斎は「自称宗家」と見るほうが適切。
sen.e: Nowadays, a niece of the 32nd head of Soryo-ke family Keishosai OGASAWARA designates herself as Soke and teaches classes at Lord Ogasawara Residence as kyojo, but it is appropriate to consider Keishosai as 'self-designated Soke' based on the three facts; (1) her school goes against the main conception that Ogasawara school has historically consisted of three manners including archery, horsemanship and courtesy of Ogasawara school, (2) her school has not performed shinji (ritual ceremonies) in temples and shrines throughout Japan, and (3) archery and horsemanship have been samurai etiquette and the secrets of the skills have been handed over to only one son.

Nowadays, Keishosai OGASAWARA, a niece of the 32nd head of the main family, calls herself Soke and teaches classes at Lord Ogasawara's Residence, but she should be considered a 'self-appointed Soke' due to the following three facts: (1) her school goes against the main idea that the Ogasawara school has historically consisted of the three arts of archery, horsemanship and courtesy; (2) her school has not performed shinji (ritual ceremonies) in temples and shrines throughout Japan; and (3) archery and horsemanship are samurai skills and have historically have been handed down to one son only.

Nowadays, Keishosai OGASAWARA, a niece of the 32nd head of the main family, calls herself Soke and teaches classes at Lord Ogasawara's Residence, but she should be considered a 'self-appointed Soke' due to the following three facts: (1) her school goes against the main idea that the Ogasawara school has historically consisted of the three arts of archery, horsemanship and courtesy; (2) her school has not performed shinji (ritual ceremonies) in temples and shrines throughout Japan; and (3) archery and horsemanship are samurai skills and have historically have been handed down to one son only.
